items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Acting SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services, Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal CounselSUBJECT:Approve Energy Services Contract with Chevron Energy Solutions and Approve Resolution #2009/2010-14 Authorizing a Lease Purchase Agreement for the Purpose of Financing the Chevron Energy Solutions Company Project, Designating the Lease Purchase Agreement as a Tax Exempt Obligation; and Authorizing and Prescribing Other Matters Related TheretoProposal In March of this year the District filled applications with the Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) for incentive funding under the California Solar Initiative Project.  The timing of submission of the Board-approved energy incentive applications ensured that the incentive rates for kilowatts per hour (kWh) of generating capacity once installed by the District would be greater for about half of our school sites.  However, to ensure the availability of the Incentives reserved by the deposit and applications, the District must comply with the California Solar Initiative guidelines, including but not limited to installation of qualifying projects.Attached is a schedule showing the rates of return per kWh and a schedule of project milestone deadlines.  During negotiations with CES the scope of the project for the first phase has been scaled down to address only the higher rate application sites and only the solar panel installation portion of the projects, all of which would generate a combined 3.7 megawatts of electrical output.  The six school sites identified for Phase 1 are:Andrew Hill High SchoolEvergreen Valley High SchoolFoothill High SchoolIndependence High SchoolSanta Teresa High SchoolW.C. Overfelt High SchoolTo preserve its deposit and the highest available rates for the above six school sites, the District must submit its Proof of Project Milestone packets to PG&E no later than October 22, 2009.  The required packet must include a legally binding contract for the installation of a qualified project.Potential Financial Impact to DistrictUnlike other California government agencies, public school districts’ ability to increase general revenues has been limited to parcel tax measures.  This project has the potential to improve revenue and at the same time decrease expenses for the District.  A solar/renewable energy installation project exchanges a monetary asset (money) for facilities/equipment assets (solar equipment) that upon completion and once in operation can decrease the demand on operational funds (for energy costs) while providing revenues (renewable energy credit) to the District.    Currently, and consistent with the Board’s directive to reduce financing costs and not use bond funds, we have developed a funding model that utilizes district capital funds and some financing.  The project as currently sized is at an amount not to exceed $24.1 million.  We are recommending a funding model where the District would contribute $15 million from Fund #35, with third party financing of $9.1 million.  The reasons for recommending this funding model is two fold.  The first reason takes into consideration the current State economy and the uncertainty of mid-year budget reductions and further deferral of State revenues.  In leaving a balance of approximately $10 million dollars in the Capital Facilities fund it would allow for temporarily borrowing of those funds for cash purposes and perhaps after the first of the calendar year an option to partially fund the second phase of the this project.  The second reason is that the rate of return on the funds invested is greater for this funding model.  FISCAL IMPACT:(1) $24,100,000 as cost of installation with a return that replaces the capital funds to fund #35 and retires the financing debt within a 25 year period.(2) Estimated approx. $1,500,000 annually to General Fund for years 1-5, under this model. FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities Fund #35, $15 million and financing of $9.1 million.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that after discussion the Board approve the contract with Chevron Energy Solutions for the Design/Build installation project for the District, to include the six school sites as identified above and in a total amount not to exceed $24.1 million.  Such project will produce in aggregate 3.7 megawatts of electrical output.
